div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Local and General
div.p: The first small dance of the season at the
Savoy Hotel will plece on Satarday,
December 21st. :
The Coast Guard Administration effected a
seizure of 78 kilos of hasheesh in the Port
Said harbour on the 6th inst.
Tho Brindiel Mail
Phe mail from Enrope via Brindisi aud Port
Said (P. and 0.) will be distributed at the
Alexandria Post Office at 9 o'clock this
evening.
The offices of The Egyptian Lignolite and
Brick Co. Litd. Cairo, lately at Rue El Maghraby,
have been transferred to Rue El Manak, Zola
Honse, facing the Banque of Salonica
The Western Oasis Railway passed the head-
quarters of the Corporation of Western Egypt
Limited, in the Oasis of Khargeh on the 7th
inst. and atthe present rate of progress should
reach the terminus by the end of the year.
The members of the Legislative Council
were unable at Saturday's meeting to come
to a decision whether to admit reporters at
their deliberations. After a stormy discussion
the President left the hall and the meeting
broke up.
At a meéting of the Belgian Colony which
was held on Saturday at the National Hotel
under the presidency of Baron de Gaiffier
d'Hestroy it was decided to form a Union
Belge for commercial and other purposes. The
officers and committee were duly elected.
Zaccaria Markakis, the Greek who murdered
his young wife a few days ago bas committed
suicide at an hotel at Tautah. The police of
Tantah having communicated with Cairo, the
deceased. wife's sister and a member of the
secret police were sent to identify the body.
Mustapha Bey Moalster, resident in the
Saida district of Cairo, notified the police yester-
day morning that the sum of L.E. 80 had been
stolen from his money box, and, suspicions
pointing to some carriers whohad been working
near the spot where the rifled box was kept,
four of them have been arrested antl an enquiry
opened,
A correspondent writes:—One of the im-
portant changes which the new régime is res-
ponsible for will be the immediate reduction
of the English Inspectorate force in the Mi-
nistry of Finance Certain of these Inspectors.
are to be transferred to the Police, but it is
possible that thé Government will not have
room for all the men who are to be dispensed
with in this Department.
A meeting will be held at the School of
Medicine, Kasr el Ainy, at 4.30 p.m. on the
12th inst. The following papers will be read :
“On the effects produced by stimulating certain
parts of the brain in Lizards” by Dr. W.A.
Wilsow and “The relationship of Growth to
Temperatare” by Mr. W.L. Balls, There will
be an exhibition of new form of apparatus
for thie exact determination of temperatures of
microscopic objsects.
The official reed on the Water: Commis-
sion is not yet issoed, butwwe are informed on
good anthority that the new report differs but
ittle from the previously expressed opinion of
Dr. Bitter, and that like him the commission
are of opinion that the dark colour of the water
is not caused by any dangerous fungi, but is
due to the presence in the wells of certain
harmless water weeds. The full report is to
presented to the Prime Minister on Wednesday.
A considerable number of the Omdarman
merchants seem to be dissatisfied with the
conditions required by the Government for
building the shops.in the new Market. The
requirements.are such, it is alleged, that the
small merchant who complies with them would
be obliged to tie up the larger part of his capital
in the building, which leaves him very little
with which to carry on his business. They are
requesting the Government to reconsider the
matter and amend the conditions in such a man-
ner as not to keep the lesser merchants and
tradesmen out of the new market.
Messrs. MacMillan and Co. will be the
publishers of Lord Cromier’s new book, "Modern
Egypt.” In the preface Lord ,Cromier states
that his object in writing this book is twofold.
In the first place he wishes to put on record
an sccurate narrative of some of the principal
events.which have occurred in Egypt and in
the Sudan. since 1876; and in the second
place to explain the results which have accrued
to Egypt from the British occupation of the
country in 1882. The work will be in two
octavo volames, and will contain two portraits
and a map.
In spite of considerable sums of money lost
every year in this country, in the attempts to
start daily papers, the passion for founding
new organs appears to be on the increase,
despite the iling acute financial
crisis. Last week we announced the foundation
of av Italian daily new at Alexandria,
“La Patria,” and ina few days time a French
daily paper will make ite appearance. It is to
-be published every mornin, and will be the
first newspaper at Alexandria to be printed
on Linotype machines. It is to be called “Les
Nonvelles’ and the editor will be Mr. Du.
mani, who edited a paper of the same name,
which after attaining considerable popularity,
suddenly disappeared. It will be printed at
the Inprimerie Mourea.

div.head: FACILITIES IN TRAINING.
div.p: FACILITIES IN TRAVELLING.
(Gazette's Special Service).
The Constantinople correspondent of the
“Morning Post” states,that the Sultan, in order
to afford greater facilities to the Mecca pilgrims,
bas given orders for the construction of a new
railway from Mecca to Arafat and for the com-
pletion of the line from Medina to Mecca, a
distance of 280 miles, before the next pilgrimage.

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTS
div.p: THE OFFICIALS SENTENCED.
The proceedings betore the Native Court
yesterday began at 9.30 am.
The advocate Mustafa El Khadem stated
in his defence that the Parquet had not proved
that Spiro Bey or Safwat had received a bribe
so neither of them were guilty of corruption:
The most important witness for the prosecution
was Mahmdnd Neghib, who was under Safwat’s
orders on the quay. He declared that Safwat
asked him for £5 as a bribe, and he reported
this to Sir, Massie Blomfield and then to the
Deputy Director General, bat as no steps were
taken he sent bis accusation to the Finance
Ministty, who sent down a delegate to enquire.
The chief of the Parquet said that in the
beginning of 1907 the Finance Ministry found
out the corruption in the Ports and Lights and
this is due to the authority, given to this
administration to appoint employées whom
they choose fit for the posts as exceptional
cases without regard to regalations, and this
is the why the officinls such as Spiro Bey
etc., began to follow the which has led to
the present case.
The Finatice Ministry then sent a delegate to
gpenan inquiry with Dixon Bey, who made strict
investigations gnd concluded that the origin
of corraption was from Spiro Bey and Attiah
Eff. in whose bands are nearly all the admini-
strative works, promotions and transfers ete.
Then the chief of Parquet pointed out how
the first witness paid a bribe to Attiah who is
the assistant of Spiro Bey.
The chief of the Parquet is of opinion that
the prisoner Attiah ought to havé sent a
reply to the registered letter of Hafer, if he
had not really received the sum of LE 54
from him ( Hafez ) therefore that Attiah
has really received this sum as a bribe for him-
self and Spiro Bey (who is absent) and con-
sequently both of them are guilty.
Sitting adjourned to 4 p.m.
The Court reassembled subsequently and
heard some more witnesses, after which the
‘Coart pronounced the following sentences :—
Socrates Spiro Bey,three years imprisonment
and a fine of L.E. 54.
Attia Effendi George, one year’s imprison-
ment and a fine of LE 54. .
These two were charged with receiving
bribes.
Mustapha Marad and Darvish Mustapha,
found guilty of falsifying documents, were each
sentenced toxine year’s imprisonment and the
former fined L.E. 50 and LE. 30 costs.
Capondan Safwat and the others were
acquitted.
The Court rose at 8 pm.

div.head: EXTRAORINARY MEETING.
div.p: We have recently published a notice of an
extraordinary general meeting in the Egyptian
Constructions Limited, which is to be held at
4 p.m. on the 21st inst: in Cairo, The company
was started in February, 1906, and is an
Nangovich Bey, Chairman, Mr. Montagu
Summers, Mr. Thomas McClure, Mr. Stanley
Dorling and Mr. GL. Pezzi The capital was
£100,000 in 100,000 shares of £1 each, with
power to increase to £200,000 by. resolution of
the Board. The shares have stood as high as 1} | time,
and 4 large number of Anglo-Egyptians have
been induced to put their capital into the
company. The reasons, for which the extra-
ordinary meeting for the 2lat inst. has been
convened appear to have aroused some criticism,
as the following letters will show. We
may mention that Mr. Thomas McClure
who appends his signature to one the
letters, retired from the board early this year.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZZETTE."
Sir,
A crisis bas arrived in the affairs of the
Egyptian Constractious Limited and much, if
not all, depends on the decision which the
shareholders will take at the extraordinary
general meeting to be held on Satarday week,
the 21st inst. At the beginning of this year
the company was in a most flourishing condi-
tion and had excellent prospects, During the
months that have elapsed a great amount of
work has been carried out and, presumably,
paid for. Nevertheless the shareholders find
that the present Board of Directors has thought
fit to convene this meeting for the purpose of
disposing of those branches of the basiness,
which.are actually carrying on the work of the
company. All shareholders ought therefore to
insist on s strict investigation of the business
carried ont during the present year, They also
should look into the conditions, ander which
the business bas been éarried out, and the
disposal of the large sums of money received.
I am, Sir,
’ Truly yours
Tuomas McClure
Alexandria, 10th December.
Sir,
Referring to the notice convening an ex-
traordipary general meeting of the Egyptian
Constructions, Limited, for the reduction of
capital, oce is amazed that any directors
shonld place sach proposals before a presam-
ably intelligent body of shareholders. Not only
did they give us only a few months ago a most
glowing account of the fature prospects of the
associated businesses, but pointed out the
undoubtedly aniqae position the company
held in the building and engineering trades
owing to the sequisition of two private con-
cerns. Without a farther word of explanation
the shareholders are now asked to authorise
a sweeping reduction of capital and the re-
sale (probably at an enormous loss) of the
businesses which were going to do so much for
the company. Surely, before submitting such
proposals the board should have given some
statement of account and the reasons for the
step they propose? Do-they want to rush
their proposals through without explanations
or discussion? In the present deplorable posi-
tion of the company the shareholders should
be in possession of full details for their very
careful consideration before being asked to ar-
rive at any decision. We shareholders are
pleased at the opportunity of meeting the
board and enquiring as to the truth of the
many anpleasant ramoors being circulated
about the company and its management, and
to the effect that even if the board’s resolu-
tions are carried, the company will be left
without working capital. It is certainly es-
seotial that the shareholders should pull to-
gether in this matter by attending the meet-
ing in fall force and appointing some of their
nomber to investigate the position, and after
discussion with the directors report to the
shareholders as to the best course to pursue.
Yours faithfally,
SHAREHOLDER.
Cairo, 10th December.
We regret to announce the death of Mrs.
Julia Theodore Ralli, a member of the well-
known Greek family, many of whom are
established in England, who died at herresidence
at San Stefano, Ramleh, yesterday afternoon
at 4 o'clook. The deceased was widow of
the late M1. Theodore Ralli, formerly President
of the Hellenic Community at Alexandria, the
wmother of Messrs. Anthony and Constantin
Ralli, of Alexandria, and mother-in-law of Mr.
Ambroise Ralli, to whom we beg to offer our
sympathies in their bereavement. The funeral
will take place at 3 p.m. to-day from the Ramleh
Railway Station and the cortege will proceed
to the Greek Cathedral.

div.head: A THREE DAY JOURNEY
ARRIVAL OF THE "HELIOPOLIS."
div.p: (From Travelling Correspondent.)
No more voyage could have....
...us a most interesting speech in whi
plained how.the company had come to be
ed. The founders of the company had
for the past few years the development of
senger traffic across the seas and had
especially attracted, a4 has all the world, by
the marvellous Atlantic service which exists
to-day. But why shoald the Atlantic have the
monopoly ? And, moreover, fast steamers had
been running across the Atlantic for several
years now, whereas the Mediterranean service
had continued its jog-trot speed of a compara-
tively few knots per hour The company was
formed, its first two boats were built, and the
maiden voyage was now being made by one of
the vessels which would place Mediterranean
steamer traffic on a level with the Atlantic.
We left Marseilles at 1.30 p.m. on Saturday
but the first day’s ron was rather unsatisfac-
tory, owing, I am told, to bad stoking. Up to
midday on Saturday we made 395 knots.
following day’s run, however, was 456 knots,
and between midday Monday and midday
yesterday we covered 458 knots, thus leaving
us 89 knots to ras, and this we did in four
hours, for it was at 4 p.m. that the engines
were stopped just outside Alexandria harbour
to await the pilot. In considering these runs it
must be remembered that, owing to the change |,
of time, Sunday to Monday midday was not
24 hours but 28b. 10 min. and Monday to
Toesday 23h. 26 min.
Before conclading this little account of our
trip I should like to mention that many are
the souvenirs which have been left behind io
the form of appreciative letters, etc. among whom
I would mention contributions by such well-
known persons as Mr. Maurice Barrts, of the
Academie Francaise, Mr. Georges Kaiser, Mr.
Paul Adam, Mr. Jules Haret, Mr. Pierre
Baudin, Mr. J. Verdier, Mr. J MacRichard
Mr. Jean d’Ardenne, Mr. Gustave Tery and | rarely
Mr. Sidney Low, who has come ont to Egypt
to write a book on the country. The following
was his contribution :—
How fair, how faint, across the years,
The City of the Sun appears,
How oft she danced before our eyes,
Beyond the buried centuries !
Superb in history's glowing pages,
Home of the gods, the priests, the mages,
The pictured stones bring back to us,
The Vision of Heredotus |
A mocking vision, so we ssid,
A vanished world !an Egypt dead !
Ah no ! She rises from the earth,
Incarnate in a later birth,
And we may see the sunrise kiss
A greater Heliopolis.
But ancient fables, in our days,
Fulfil themselves in wondrous
Across the heaving wastes of sea !
Well now the tale is true again ;
The moving isle is on the main.
No thing of post's gossamer,
But twelve good thousand ‘tons of her ;
Palace and town and house and street,
With iron hungs, that breathe and beat,
The City of the Sun, once more,
Wings her swift way to Egypt's shore,
And bears us through the Middle Sea,
Tn Cleopatra's loxury ;
Bears us from Northern fog and frost,
To that enchanted summer cosst,
Our Island of the Bleet she is,
The great ship "Héliopolis."
S.S. Heliopolis, at Sea.
SIDNEY LOW.

div.head: THE FUTURE OUTLOOK.
div.p: VI.
As soon as the present feverish activity
prevailing at Port Sudan comes to an end and
all the Government buildings are erected, it is
very probable that the town wilk, lose a large
number of its civilian inbabitants and for some
years to come will remain in a state of
stagnancy awaiting the development of the
Sudan. In. the town and its neighbourhood
there is nothing to attract a resident population
except the desire of making money speedily.
The climate is extremely hot and damp during
the greater part of the year, Beyond the town
stretches a dreary plain with only mimosa
thorns for vegetation. The horizon is bounded
by the desolate. Hadendowa mountains ten
miles away. There are no amusements in the
evening. and the distractions. prevailing at
Egyptian ports ate probibited by-a paternal
Government. Sunstroke is very prevalent in
the summer and the dainp climate of the Red
Sea enfeebles the constitution of Europeans.
Living is.very. expensive, Eggs cost P.T. 1 a
piece and cabbages P.T. 5, meat is P.T. 5 per
oke and itis not always possible to obtain
Deef, as the Hadendowas refuse to sell, for
these Arabs teckon their wealth by their cattle
and do not regard.the possession of money as
an estimate of wealth. There is not a single
inducement to tempt the European to live in
Port Sudan save money-making, and as .soon
as the Government. contracts run out and
there is no further need for European labour,
the population: will inevitably begin to dwin-
dle. The ships will cesse to call there as soon
as the large consignments of Government
material from Europe are no longer forthi-
coming and then Port Sudan will enter ona
period of inaction until the Sudan begins to
develop.
COMPARISON WITH SUAKIM.
It was thonght by the enthusiastic supporters
of the scheme. that the new tewn wouldbe
able to successfully compete with Suakim, but
the old Red Sea port of the Sadan will go on
and prosper while Port Sudan is. still waiting.
The great advantage of Suakim isthat ithas.s
large and most fertile areas of country to the
South, which is »rapidly developing into the
most important, cotton producing centre in the
Sudan. Port Sudan on the othér hand has no
fertile hinterland of any sort or kind The only
export of conseqnence from Port Sudan is
gum and and all that could be taken away in
a single large steamer. At Suakim the cotton
exports are. inoreasing enormously. During the
cotton season from January to August last
44,655 cantars of unginned cotton, valued at
LEB. 43,980, were exported and 13,871
cantars of ginned cotton, of the value of LE.
41,545, making the total value ofthe cotton
exports L E..85,525, The Tokar cotton area is
increasing and every year it is cultivated with
more success.
THE KASSALA TRADE.
- The Government consider that. if a line of
railway wus brought from Kassala to the Nile-
Red Sea Line, all the Kassala trade will be
brought to Port Sudan, But it mast be remem-
bered that all the traders with Kassala reside
in Saakim and they will do their utmost to
bring dl that trade to Snakim. The Govern-
ment do not appear to reilise the intensitey of |
the feeling, which binds the Suakimese to
their old bome. Why should they be so fou lish
as to leave their native town for Port Sadan,
whose prospects are, after all, somewhat vision-
ary ss far as the immediate future is concerned?
If the native trader were to leave Suakim he
would lose all the value of his large comfort-
able house there, which would remain empty,
in order to dwell in the wooden shanties of
Port Sudan. Trade rontes are ever conservative
and Suakim will long continue to flourish
while Port Sudan is just managing to eke oat
a precarious existence.
THE FUTURE.
When the six hundred metres of quays are
ready and the Government: buildings are com-
plete, the labourers will depart and Port Sudan
will relapse into a semi-deserted state. The
dnly export trade in sight is that of gum in
transit from Khartoum, which is about six
thousand tons 4 year. ‘The rest of the exports
are about from five to six thousand tons, mak-
ing a total export of twelve thousand tons per
annum. The money thet actually remains in
Port Sadan from handling this transit trade is
about L.E 1,500. The imports at the outside
amount to thirty thousand tons, not inclading
the Government imports. Of these imports only

a very small part remains in the town and the
profit actually remaining from building these
imports and the commision may be estimated at
PT. 15 per ton or L.E. 3,000 per annum from
this transit trade. There is a little local trade
in timber and dhurra for the looal require-
ments of a town of four thousand inhabitants,
three thousand of whom are natives.
What then is to be the outlook for Port
Sudan? We are of opinion that the only ontlook
in the immediate,future must be one of
patient resignation, say tor the next ten years,
antil the Sadan makes some substantial pro-
gress. The vast irrigation-works necessary ‘for
the «development of the Sudan have not yet
begun and they will take many years to
complete. The country, depopulated by the
excesses of the Dervishes, has to await the
coming of new generations to fill up the voids
made by their massacres. All this will take
time and it is childish to expect any im-
mediate results, But as soon as this develop-
ment begins to bear fruit, the effect will be at
once evident in Port Sadan, whose harbour
will increast in importance with the growth
of Sudanese exports. To expect that it is to
at once spring intoexistence as a flourishing
harbour is absard, especially in a cogntry sit-
uated as the Sudan is, for its fatdre is ne
cessarily bound up withthe devélopment of a
very slowly moving country. But although Port
Sadan has many years of stagnant expectation
and of hope deferred betore it, thete is every
reason to believe that it will ultimately justify
its existence.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
div.p: THE COPTS AND NATIONALISTS.
All the efforts of the Moslem Nationalists
to induce the Copts to join them in political
agitation have »been fruitless, The Coptic
point of view. is well expressed in "Al Watan",
the Cairo Coptic organ, which makes the
followingcomment on the Nationalistic leaders
and their real aims :—
We have never doubted for a moment that
personal ends and religions motives were at
the bottom of everything, done or said by
these journalists who are supposed to be the
leaders of political parties in Egypt. Mustafa
Kamel goes to.the extreme end and pushes
forward as hard as. be can, because, he.eandind
no other means for living. Were heto agcestain
now that a show of moderation would increase
his income or enhance his fame he would
become as moderate aa you like to-morrow. So
are Sheikh Ali and his supporters counselling
moderation and denouncing the extreme party
because it pays them better to do so now.
When they find it in their parsonal interest
to be wildly extreme in their criticism of the
present regime they will not hesitate a moment
in outatepping even the bounds of “Al-Lewa”
in their frenzied denunciation. They have done
this on many: an occasion and they are most
willing to do.sd whemever they think. it better
for their pockets. In fact they bave no natural
or real feelings except such as they.expressed
aften the Denshwaa incident and snoh as “Al-
Lewa” has been always evincing in these
years. Perhaps our readers will remember that
we foresaw the right thing early this year
when we explained that by mutual arrangement
or by common inspiration our presen day
moderates were to cool down and leave the
honour of permanent heat in the boatile cam-
paign against the British rule to “Al-Lewa”’ for
some time. We have now full evidence that
our suspicions were well founded and that
the moderation of these “comrades” is at the
best untrue.
Take their attitude towards Christians in
general and Copts in particular, as an example
of their patriotism aud you will find that re-
ligious fanaticism is the suin-aod-essence of
all their politics and all the doings of their
dives. Both the extreme and the moderate
leaders have been calling upon the Oopts of
late to join their parties and pretending: the
most innocent desire to see Moslems and Copts
united as Egyptians to defend the common in
terests. The leader of the extreme wing re-
cently hired certain nobedies among the
Copts to say that they are his faithfal follow
ers. He eve invented Coptic names for some
of his fabricated letters on this swbject. Yet
the slightest provocation of the old prejudice
or of the dominating fanaticism will speedily
unmask these patriots and make them let the
cat out of the bag as they have done in ctwo
cases of recent date.
One of the two cases above referred to was
that of Salib Bey Claudios, a most capable
and trasworty servant of the Postal Adminis-
tration who was lately promoted to a high
position. Salib Bey is almost without equal
in hissérious and straightforward performance
of duties and in the wide range of his acquire-
ments and experience. He has gained this
belated-recognition of his services by the in-
evitable tight of seniority and the unrivalled
record of his services. Yet because he hap-
pens to be a Christian and a Copt his promo-
tion was bitterly criticised in “Al-Lewa” and
“Al-Moayad”, both editors well knowing that
Salib Bey was far soperior in all the require-
ments of his new post to any of the friends
they would bave apoointed in his place.
The second case refers to the omdeh of
Deirout, a village in Upper Egypt. That digni-
tary was some days ago relieved of his duties
and a notable Copt eslected to fill bis piece,
Of course, the new omdel was not selected on
aceount of his religion, for s Copt ie likely to
lose rather than gain on that account~ nowa-
days. But ovr moderate and sincere friend “Al
Moayed” could not hide bis great disappoint-
ment although the ease was hardly worthy of
his great seal. He poured his venom unreser-
vedly the eppointment of a
Christian omdeh end threw the mask of mo-
his
real metal this time and proved once again to
all and sundry that toleration and moderation
mean absolutely nothing to him. Like his rival
of “Al Lewa,” he is a dangerous agitator and a
fanatic of the species. 494, .we pro-
foundly regret to say, the principles and pur-
poses of these rivals are shared by millions.

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE.
div.p: RRADY MADE CHOTHING.
The following statistics déaling with the im-
sports of ready made clothing into Egypt
during the past five years clearly demonstrate
that the trade ieateadily increasing'in volame
year by year, and that Great Britain has only
a very insignificant share of the market, despite
the fact that she ranks third on the list of
competing countries. It will aise be observed
that whilet Austria does 65% of the trade, her
nearest rival (France) is only credited with
Imports of ready made clothing into Bgypt
in L.E. for the years 1902, 1903, 1904, 1905,
As a matter of interest we may mention
that in 1897 the total imports were, L.E.
129,000, whereas for the first nine months of
the present year the figures were L.E. 279,491.
These latter returns, by the way, show an in-
crease Of L,B. 54.000 over the same period in
1906, so we are still on the upward movement.
For Austria to have almost a monopoly of
the Egyptian ready made clothing trade, it is
obvious that there must be gome exceptional
feature in her favour. As far-as we can gather,
such factor lies not, as one might. expect, in
having large up-to-date factories with all the
latest machinery, put rather in her very cheap
labour.
Briefly but, the system appears to be for the
goods to be cut out in the factory and then
given to contractors (or, as they are termed,
master tailors) for completion. These men in
torn-either ran small workshops in which ap-
prentice labour is mainly employed, or they
give the sewing ont to the peasants-in: the vil-
lages, especially during the winter months
The rules—which are upheld by the State—
of the Tailors’ Guilds re apprentices greatly.
assist the above mentioned master tailors. in
turning out the goods with the least possible
expense. It appears that before a man can
commence in business as a tailor on. his own
account, he must have served at least four years
asan apprentice (during which he receives
merely his board and ledging) and about sight
years as an improver at a very small wage. It
is no exaggeration to say that a large amount
ofthe work on ready made clothing is done by
apprentices and improvers.
Another feature in favour of Austria is the
fact that the trade in Egypt is more or less in |
the hands of three or four big firms, which have
houses in Vienna and so import direct. They
have their own branches in the larger Egyptian
towns, and we understand, some of them are
also interested in the smaller clothing shops in
the villages. The combination is so strong that,
although both England and Germany have at-
tempted to get a footirg the efforts they have
made in this direction have so far been unsuc
cessful.
It must also be remembered that, for the Jast
40 or 50 years Austria has been in the Egyptian
clothing trade and she, therefore, thoroughly
anderstands the-reqairements of the market.
Her Government, too, encourages the industry
as far as possible by waiving all import-duties
on materials. brought into the country and
afterwards exported in the form of clothing.
The main centre for the trade in, Austria is
Vienna with some 3% villages in the neighbour: | _
hood After the goods are finished they are
packed for expott ip atrong: mooden cases, each
some 1.20 metres (47 inghes) long by J metre
(89 inches) high, and costing about 5/6. The
cases (which are sometimes lined with water-
proof paper) usuglly contain clothes to the
value of abont L.E. 100. The freight and in-
suranos from’ Vienna to Alexandria, may be
reckoned at something like 2% or 3% of the
cost, ahd a further 10% to 11% must be added
for quay duties, landing charges, customs and
clearing expenses, and cartage, to shop or ware-
house.
(British Bulletin Chamber of Commerce)

ARMY AND NAVY.
(From Our Own Corespondent).
London, December 4th.
The croiser “Diana,” Captain H.S. Grant,
which has taken up the duties of senior naval
officer's ship on. the Egyptian coasts, has put
in one half of ber two year commission. The
Diana’s new commission was probably the
cause of her failing off in gunnery this year
Last year she was third in the return ofthe
Méditerranean Fleet, but this year she will not
occupy so high a place according to a semi-
official statement.
Lieutenant F. Carne Rasch, the senior sub.
of the 6th Dragoon Guards, Mhow, who has
been selected for service with the Egyptian i
Army, entered the Essex Regiment, in 1901, |
and transferred from the Pompadoers to the
Carabiniers in September, 1903. Curiously. his
father, Sir Frederick Carne Rasch, Bart, M P.,
served in the Pompadours and in the Carabi
niera. Mr. Rasch went through the Transvaal
operations of 1901-02 with the Exsex Regiment's
1st Battalion (Queen's medal with five clasps
Another selection for the Egyptian Army
is that-of Lieutenant P.M. Larken, Army
Service Corps, London. This officer got bis
Comminsion directly into the Army Service
Corps in January, 1902.
In naval circles it is stated that no further
reductions are to be made in any of the
squadrons sérving abroad.
It is believed that the German budget
deficit will have a powerful influence on the
shipbuilding programme of that country
By the departare of the 3rd Battalion Wor-
ceatershire Regiment for the Cape, the Alder-
shot command has lost its best shooting batta-
lion. twas the magnificent musketry record
of the 3nd Battalion, and the good record of
the 4th Battalion, now in Malta, which saved
both from sbolition when “reform” swept the
docks recently.
No more is to be heard of the Seott ford
incident. There is a general feeling that both
admirals were wrong, and that it would be
better to let the thing drop into the limbo
specially reserved for such incidents, It will,
however, not be the fault of some old salts if
the incident will not be one of the pegs on
which itis proposed to hang the mach talked
of inquiry into the efficiency of the Royal
Navy
Those pessimists who are always crying out
about the decadence of Britixh naval supre
macy very often do more harm than good to
the causethey would sepport by the eternal
ery of “wolf”. For instance, it has been stated |
that we are on the eve ot being swamped in
the matter of Dreadhoughis by Germany and
France, not to mention the United States. A
close research into the qgeetion shews that
according to our present naval programme
Great Britain will have a fieet of four Dread: |
noughts, and three Invincible creisers in being |
before Germany has a single Dreadrought
ready for the pennant, whilst neither France
or The United States will have a single ship
ready. To put it in other words, Great Britain,
at the present time has one Dreadnought in
commission, three Dreadnoughts ahd three
Invincibles have been launched, and no other
power has a single one launched. Germany
sa down two Dreadnoughts so recently as
last October
Captain J. N. Crawford, ist Battalion Royal
Inniskilling Fusiliers, Crete, has been ordered
home to the regimental depot, Omagh, in relief
of Major Jones, whose tour is about to expire.
The 2nd Battalion Sufflolk Regiment will
leave Aden on the 11th inst. Yor Parkhurst,
Isle of Wight. The “Assaye” will call at Aden
on that date to put off the ist Bedforas and
take on the Sulfolks, the origiual arrangement
having been altered.
Lieutenant Colonel W.J. Baker, Royal Army
Medical Corps, who goes oot to Egypt nett
month, has been in the medical branch of the
sérvice since 1882. His first professional ex~
perience of active service was in the late war
in South Africa when he did good work
amongst the sick and wounded during the
operations in Orange River Colony, the Trans-
vaal and Cape Colony (Queen's medal with
two clasps).
The 3rd Battalion King’s Royal Rifle Corps
is looking forward eagerly to its coming tour
of foreign service, the first spell of which will
be spent in classic Crete. It was last in Malta
command in 1882, going from there to Egypt
for the campaign of that year, and the sub-
sequent Soudan campaigns, at the conclusion
of which it recruited itself in Cyprus. It was
through the South African War.

div.head: PERUNA A WONDERFUL BOON IN MY OLD AGE.
div.p: MRS. MAHALA REID, Corbyville, Ont., Canada, writes:
"Your celebrated remedles have been a wanderful boon to me in my old age.
. "I have not been in so good health for soveral years as now. I was troubled with constipation, pheumatism and kidney trouble.

"A little over two years ago, I com- pletely lost my health, becoming al- most helpless, when a dear friend sent me your remedles, Perunasad Manalo. I began to take them, following the direetions on the bottle. I very soon began to feel benefited by thefr use and continued to take them.
"I am now completely recovered from the above ailments, in fact, better than I have been for years past. I cannot praise the remedies too highly and will always recommend them to others."
Constipation is almost sure to set up other derangements.
Retained accumulations within the bowels are partly resbaorbed into the gyeters, producing sometimes rheuma- tism, sometimes kidney trouble.
The blood being surcharged with acids, which ordinarily find their es- ape through the bowels when they are regular, rheumatism is the result.
Acid blood forms eryatals, which ac- cumulate about the ligaments, carti-
lages and sometimes the bones in the joints.

Such morbid accumalations of blood throw extry work upon the kidneys. The kidneys being unable to perform the unusual labor of exereting these poisona, ofton give way and kidney trouble is the result.
Permanent relief cannot be resnona- bly expected excaps by correcting the
constipation.
Regular bowels are a great safe- guard to health. Peruna and Man-
alin are unexcelled the world over
for chronic diseases affecting the bowels and kidneys.
Mrs. W. W. Lemaster, 8127 MoAtee, Ave., Louisville, Ky., writes :
"I suffered for twenty-six yeara with bladder snd kidsey trouble, and being
advised to give Peruna a trial, I did so. Eight botter of Peruna and three bot- tles of Manalin entirely cured me."
For special direetions everyone would read "The Ills of Life," a copy, of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- presseed by our correspondents, but we wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit—within certainneceasary limits— free discussion.
COOK'S NILE TRIPS.
To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"
Sir,—Having just returned to Cairo from a
holiday trip up the Nile on Messrs T. Cook
and Son’s S.S. “Rameses” 1 cannot resist the
temptation to write a few words in honest
praise of the excellent arrangements which
were made by that firm for our comfort both on
board and on.the river banks; hoping that you
will be able to find space for my letter in your
valuable paper, as I believe a short record of
the considerate treatment we all receiyed from
Cook's employés will be of general interest and
especially 80 to those tourists who cdntemplate
making the Nile trip this season.
The antiquities and scenery are continually
being admired and written about, and why
should we overlook the merits of the agency
which enables usto travel in luxoriant ease from
the farthest corner of the globe to see these
works of nature and man, which otherwise we
should never visit.
The advantages to be derived from travel-
ling c/o. Cooks are well known, bot it was
certainly an eye-opener to me to observe the
facilities which were so readily scoorded to our
“party at every turn: No single hitch occurred
daring the entire three weeks and the brilliant
manner in which not unfrequent difficulties
Cook and Son but it is literally impossible to
withhold applause of true merit, and even the
most critical traveller and epicure cwho has
made the voyage to Assouan by one of their
tourist steamers cannét help realising to, its
fall extent the trath of the saying that “Cook
is the King of Egypt”.
Yours faithfully
A Passenger.
Cairo. 9th December.

div.head: A REVIEW OF A GREAT INDUSTRY (1742- 1907.)
div.p: Sheffield is probably the principal city in
the world sg regards silver-plated work ; in
fact, something like 100 tons of silver plate
are prod: there every year.
The processs of Sheffield plating, which has
been renowned for a century and a half on
account gf ite darability, was originally
discovered throagh an accident by Thomas
Bolsover about the year 1742, the component
parts being copper and silver, but as is
eee case.with the originators of a
great idea, he did not realise the momertoos
importance of lis discovery and it was reserved
for a Mr. Hancock to utilise the principle, and
show the great advantages to which copper,
plated in this few method, could be applied.
He atilised it forthe working of sack kinds
of domestic ware and table decorations which
ap to that period had been exclasively made
in silver, viz :—tea urns, ton sets, epernes,
salvers, spoons, forks, &e. The execellency of
the manafactore is proven by the fact that
many pieces of plate made between the year
1742 and 1762 are still in existence, showing
practically little signs of usage. Originally
the copper was plated on one side only; bot
in later years, meats were found to enable the |,
plater tocoat the copper en both sides, aud
such perfection did this art of Sheffield plat-
ing sttain, tht it was celebrated“ throaghout
the known world Previous to 1784 it was
illegal to stamp any sign or letters apon an
article of silver plate under a penalty of £100
bat owing to inferior articles comipg on the
market, it beeame necessary for high-class
makers to protest themselves sod their goods
stamped withs significant omrk under which
their initials were invariably placed. Por ina
tance, at the botten of a miver might be
stamped a Lion, with the initials “A.B.” beneath,
probably representing strength, and made by
Albert Brown ; so all goods of Albert Brown's
manufacture would be thes stamped. This, of
urea, was @ primitive form of advertining.
The process of maenfactare was slow, neater
ally expensive, aud consequently there arose
a demand for a more expeditions form of
production, and, as necessity brings invention,
ao after period of 100 years, namely, about
1845, came the introduction of electro plating,
which instantly revolutionined the system ot
manufacturing Sheffield pine; for whilst in
the old process the platér-produced the feet,
handles, &e at a great cost of time out of solid
sheets of silver, supported by scifer, and
fastened so that silver was onlt to
view and wear, it the new system, the article
was placed in a bath, the silver deposited by
au electrical process, and the manual laboor
thus saved, prodaced the desired result. Im-
mediately, the trade advanced by leaps snd
bounds ; factories of every description sprang
up, giving employment to thousands of per-
sons, another great industry was added to the
long role owning discovery to the creative
genius of the Anglo Saxon race, Naturally
there were at once, good bad, and indifferent
mandfacturers and the necessity again arose
for these whe desired to be knows ae The
producers af the highest “claw of goods, to
stamp their mark open the articles tthey
produced.
One of the leading firme whe ere now manu-
factoring electro plate at Sheffield, is :—- The
Association of Diamond Merchants, Jewellers,
and Silversmiths, Limited, whose London ad--
dress is Trafalgar Square, and who have always
prodaced the highest ideals in elegance of
desing, heaviest deposit of silver, and highest
quality and finish ; on this account they are
therefore justly celebrated throughout the
world, and to distizigaish their goods from all
other wakers, they plsce upon each article
their Registered Mark “A.D M. Sheffield Al”
which is s gagrantee that the article is of the
highest quality. A spoott or fork stamped
“A D M. Sheffield Al” therefore, is guaranteed
to wear for.30 years, and at the same time, the
cost is only half that of solid: silver, and wears
equally as well. Doubtless the majority of the
readers of this paper are already well acquaint-
ed with the world-wide reputation of this firm,
bat should they be desirous of purchasing from
a local tradesman or ordering through a ship
per, any articles of “Sheffield” Plate it ix abso-
lutely negessary to insist that the article bears
the Registered Stamp. Imitation is the sin
cerest form of flattery, and it is a very lucrative
business to copy an article of the highest
quality in a cheaper plate, and charging the
price of the former.
The Association of Diamond Merchants,
Jewellers, and Silversmiths, Limited, publish «
descriptive catalogue with illustrations and
prices of their productions in “Sheffield’ Plate,
which they will forward free to anyone upon
application.

In accordance with a resolution taken by
the Board of Directors of this Company to
make the Final Call of 5/- per Share on the —
Ordinary Shares, I hereby beg to-notify Share-
holders, that said Final: Call of 5/- per Share
becomes payable on 28th December 1907 at
the National Bank of Egypt Alexandria and
Cairo.
Call Notices will be duly issued.to Share i
holders who must pay the amounts due by
them to the Bank on the above mentioned date.
L. Des Clayes.
Secretary in Egypt.
